content:
AUSTRALIA

Boart Longyear (BLY AT) - Co. H1 net AUD 2.0mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 16.0mln Y/Y, announces 300 for 1 share consolidation. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. H1 RCOP net AUD 135mln vs. Prev. AUD 296mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 10.3bln vs. Prev. AUD 10.2bln Y/Y, targeting to lower costs by AUD 100mln per year and will sell 50 retail sites. (Newswires)

FlexiGroup (FXL AT) - Co. FY net AUD 61.7mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 9.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Healius (HLS AT) - Partners Group (PGHN SW) is said to be looking at the Co. (AFR)

Inghams Group (ING AT) - Co. FY net AUD 126.2mln vs. Exp. AUD 111.0mln, rev. AUD 2.49bln vs. Prev. AUD 2.37bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Northern Star Resources (NST AT) - Co. FY net AUD 154.7mln vs. Prev. AUD 194.1mln Y/Y, rev. rose 45.3% Y/Y to AUD 1.40bln, Co. makes cash offer of AUD 0.33/Shr for Echo Resources. (EAR AT). (Newswires)

Pilbara Minerals (PLS AT) - Co. reaches binding terms with South Korea’s POSCO for a JV to build and operate an LCE primary lithium hydroxide downstream chemical processing plant. (Newswires)

Reliance Worldwide Corp (RWC AT) - Co. FY net AYD 133.0mln vs. Prev. AUD 66.0mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 1.10bln vs. Prev. AUD 0.55bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Sandfire Resources (SFR AT) - Co. FY net AUD 106.5mln vs. Prev. AUD 123.0mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Silver Lake Resources (SLR AT) - Co. FY normalized net AUD 16.7mln vs. Prev. AUD 16.2mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Spark Infrastructure (SKI AT) - Co. H1 HY profit before loan interest and tax AUD 140.7mln vs. Prev. AUD 153.3mln Y/Y, EBITDA AUD 426.4mln vs. Prev. AUD 418.3mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT) - Co. FY net AUD 5.5bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.2bln Y/Y, profit after tax cont. ops. AUD 1.94bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.41bln Y/Y, rev. rose 4.3% Y/Y to AUD 27.92bln, declares special dividend AUD 1.00/Shr

Other News - Australia is working to court India as a consistent buyer of Australian coal as tensions with China and other countries lowering their purchases weigh on the coal sector. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

TEPCO (9501 JT) - Co. may decommission nuclear reactor at the Kashiwazaki Kariwa power plant. (Newswires)

Financials - Japan’s 3 megabanks are to form collaboration agreement with several African financial services providers to open up Africa to greater investment from Japan. (Newswires)

Other News Japanese PM Abe is to reshuffle cabinet and LDP executives next month. (Newswires)

Japan Ministry of Finance is to seek JPY 25.0tln in funds for debt service costs in FY20 budget which is an increase of 1.6% Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Other News - South Korea PM Lee said South Korea and Japan should find a solution before pact ends in November. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said he wants a deal with China only if it is a good and fair deal for the US, while he thinks he will make a deal with China and is confident that China is sincere in wanting a trade deal. Trump reiterated criticisms that China is taking hundreds of billions per year from the US but also stated the US has collected tariffs of nearly USD 100bln and that China’s economy has recently taken a hit with 3mln jobs lost. (Newswires)

US President Trump said we will start to negotiate shortly and believes we will make a deal as China does not want to lose its supply chains but suggested that US companies should leave China if a deal is not reached. Trump also stated that China called US trade negotiators last night and want to return to the negotiation table, while he replied that anything is possible and that the US is in a much better position now than at any time in trade negotiations when asked if he could delay planned tariffs on China. Furthermore, Trump also noted that communications are going on “at the highest level” with Chinese officials after being questioned about China's denial of any phone call. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry said they resolutely oppose the US's new tariffs and warned that China will take further steps to protect their interests if the US enacts new tariffs. The Foreign Ministry added that trade disputes should be resolved through talks and that it was not aware of a US-China weekend phone call. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said top China and US negotiators have not held talks in the past few days, but the two sides have been keeping contact at a technical level, while he added that China has not changed position and will not cave to US pressure. (Twitter)

PBoC urged banks to use the LPR as the main reference in loans as soon as possible and for banks to remove implicit floor in lending rates, while it reiterated banks are to increase lending support to small companies. (Newswires)

Indian government is likely to use additional INR 1.48trln dividend from RBI to partly fund a fresh stimulus package for the economy, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said EU are tough negotiators but that does not mean UK will not get a deal, while he reiterated the backstop must be removed from the agreement. PM Johnson suggested that EU tends to take talks to the last minute and that if there is a no-deal, substantial sums would be made available to spend domestically from the EUR 39bln Brexit bill. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he thinks he will make a deal with the EU without imposing auto tariffs and suggested the EU are very hard to get a deal with. President Trump also reiterated criticism that US has been losing money to the UK, while he stated US and Germany have reached agreements on a lot of things including trade and that he hopes he does not have to consider tariffs on German autos. (Newswires)

French President Macron said a very good accord was found on the French digital tax with an agreement to be unveiled in 2020 and stated that the French digital tax will be scrapped once an international agreement is found. (Newswires)

Italy's 5-Star and PD were reportedly on track towards an agreement where Conte can return as PM according to two PD sources, while PD leader Zingaretti said the meeting with Di Maio was positive and talks are going ahead to form a new government which he is optimistic a deal with 5-Star will be reached but declines to comment on Conte returning as PM. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian President Rouhani said he is open to talks with the West although there were separate reports that Iran has rejected French President Macron's proposal for negotiations over its ballistic missile programme and regional issues. (Newswires)

 

US

US Durable Goods Jul 2.1% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.9%, Rev. 1.8%). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Early risk-off trade was banished after US President Trump's friendly remarks on China tariffs was cited for renewed risk appetite. The more constructive risk sentiment was built on after the G7 summit, where there were a few 'deals' announced, and a level of unity that was not seen at last year's meeting in Canada. Equities traded firmer, and ignored 2s10s meandering in and out of inversion -- something which would have led to more distinct equity downside just last week, some desks have also cited. Crude was largely following overall risk sentiment (equities), though saw some downside on positive geopolitical developments regarding Iran (President Macron has tried to broker a meeting between Presidents Rouhani and Trump, the latter of which seemed amenable to meeting, and even to the prospect of making a deal). Treasuries, meanwhile were lower, with 10-year yields recovering Friday's slide, though SPX has not risen back to Friday's highs. Some desks last week were writing that global macro funds were on the side lines dip-buying, on the rationale that US economic fundamentals are still sound. Gold also continues to trade in positive territory, in a sign that not all risk assets have bought into Monday's risk on. The Trump-inspired trade optimism has fed through to the trade sensitive stocks, which lead gains on Monday, including Apple (AAPL), industrials (UTX, BA, DE) and chipmakers (INTC, NVDA, AMD, MU). Bristol-Myers (BMY) and Celgene (CELG) outperformed after agreeing to divest Celgene’s Otezla drug to Amgen (AMGN) post completion of their pending merger; Amgen opened lower on the news. PDC Energy (PDCE) surged as it announced the acquisition of competitor SRC Energy (SRC). Vici Properties and Dish Networks (DISH) benefitted from upgrades at Morgan Stanley and Raymond James respectively. Beyond Meat (BYND) surged on a KFC (YUM) collaboration. TechnipFMC (FTI) caught a bid on announcing it would separate into two separately public traded companies. S&P 500 +1.1% at 2879, NASDAQ-100 +1.5% at 7575, Dow Jones +1.1% at 25902.

Treasuries were in negative territory, largely on optimism regarding a medley of factors, although it is notable that yields, while largely recovering the downside seen on Friday, have not matched the optimism of equity markets, which were trading up by over a percent at one point. It has taken yields longer to rise (at the time equities were up around 1%, yields were only up by around 1bps across the curve; however, at pixel time, equities are off the highs by a margin, and yields are up around 3bps at the short end, and around 2bps at the long-end. Curve spreads are relative flat (+/- 1bps for the major spreads, at settlement); 2s10s once again entered inversion in the European afternoon, although it did not have a detrimental impact on the risk environment. Some traders are more interested by this week’s bund auctions, rather than Treasury auctions. The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (Tue, USD 40bln), new 5-year note (Wed, USD 41bln) and new 7-year note (Thu, USD 32bln). Analysts at UBS say this week will bring USD 85bln of cash (excluding SOMA holdings) but including around USD 76bln of redemption, as well as around USD 8.5bln of coupons. US T-note futures (U9) settled 5+ ticks lower at 130-25.

US Market Wrap 26th August 2019: Equities rally as G7 calms investors nerves
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: G7 provides generally positive tone, with a digital tax compromise and Trump spurring China optimism; Iran pushes back on Trump and Macron negotiation proposals; PD and 5-Star move closer to new Italian government.
  • COMING UP: Data: German GDP (Detailed), US Consumer Confidence. Event: Fed Discount Rate Minutes. Speakers: RBA’s Debelle, BoE’s Broadbent & Tenreyro, ECB’s de Guindos, Norges Banks Matsen. Auctions: German EUR 5bln 2021 & US USD 40bln 2yr.

* MARKET WRAP: Early risk-off trade was banished after US President Trump's friendly remarks on China tariffs was cited for renewed risk appetite. The more constructive risk sentiment was built on after the G7 summit, where there were a few 'deals' announced, and a level of unity that was not seen at last year's meeting in Canada. Equities traded firmer, and ignored 2s10s meandering in and out of inversion -- something which would have led to more distinct equity downside just last week, some desks have also cited. Crude was largely following overall risk sentiment (equities), though saw some downside on positive geopolitical developments regarding Iran (President Macron has tried to broker a meeting between Presidents Rouhani and Trump, the latter of which seemed amenable to meeting, and even to the prospect of making a deal). Treasuries, meanwhile were lower, with 10-year yields recovering Friday's slide, though SPX has not risen back to Friday's highs. Some desks last week were writing that global macro funds were on the side lines dip-buying, on the rationale that US economic fundamentals are still sound. Gold also continues to trade in positive territory, in a sign that not all risk assets have bought into Monday's risk on.

* G7: Comments out of the G7 somewhat surprisingly set markets up for a risk-on day; heading into the week, the perception was that the G7 may only stoke further downside risks in wake of trade escalation between the US and China at the end of last week. However, we have seen US/Japan reaching an 'in principle' trade deal, to be signed in September; Trump also said he thought a deal can be made with the EU on trade, without imposing auto tariffs; there seems to have been progress on the 'digital tax' from the US perspective. Trump also appeared to imply he was flexible on China tariffs, saying it was possible for their imposition to be delayed; some also cited the 'positive' remarks from China Vice Premier Liu He (calling for 'calm'). Additionally, the G7 statement alluded to many of the factors that Trump is pushing for (some were not even expecting a statement, so the fact we got one is a positive): the statement backed WTO reform in order to safeguard intellectual property (one of Trump's gripes with China), the group commits to 'free and open' trade (a common Trump mantra), and the group reaffirmed the 1984 Sino/US agreement on Hong Kong - none of the discord that characterised the 2018 G7 meeting was explicitly evident.

* US/CHINA: After the most recent escalations of the trade conflict, China Vice Premier Liu He called for calm; US President Trump has claimed that China called US trade negotiators on Sunday night, and wants to return to the negotiation table - a claim dismissed by the ubiquitous Global Times Editor, who is often seen as a proxy for the official China government position; Trump rejected this denial, reiterating that talks were taking place at the highest level. Trump also added that China President Xi was a great leader, and said the US will make a further statement on China. Trump was asked if he could delay planned tariffs on China, to which the President replied that anything was possible, and he added that US was now in a much better position now than at any time in trade negotiations; this led to an injection of 'risk-on' trade in the markets, and set the tone for the day's trade. Meanwhile, many desks have been revising down growth forecasts in China, and have warned that it may even lead to a lower growth profile in the US too. At the concluding G7 press conference, Trump said he wants a deal with China only if it was a good deal and a fair deal for the US, then repeated a familiar remark, saying he thinks he will make a deal with China.

* US DURABLE GOODS: Durable Goods: Durable goods came in at 2.1%, up from the prior 1.8% (Revised lower by 10bps) and beating expectations for 1.2%, due to a rebound in Boeing (BA) orders. Initially seeming like a strong report, however core readings were mixed. Ex-Transport durable goods declined 0.4%, falling from the prior 0.8% gain. The Ex Defense measure slowed to a 1.4% gain from a prior 3.1% and non-defense ex-air beat expectations for a 0.1% decline but slowed from the prior 0.9% to 0.4%. Pantheon Macroeconomics note the core figures do remain sluggish; the non-defense ex air measure did rise to 0.4%, however it was the first time since October 2016 that it dipped below the prior year’s level. The Y/Y fall was 0.5%, however, Pantheon state for now, the underlying trend seems more flatter than lower. Overall, the current orders are soft rather than terrible, but the desk notes a deterioration appears more likely than more of the same across the remainder of H2 as the NFIB survey clearly shows a sustained downward shift in capital spending over the next few months. In terms of GDP, IFI note that the poor core shipments, -0.7% M/M, shows trade uncertainty is taking its toll and weighing on this element of GDP.

* IRAN: Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif attended the G7 summit over the weekend for side-line meetings with French President Macron in efforts to ease US-Iran tensions. Trump said he was aware in advance that Macron had invited Zarif, and in his comments dialled down some of the usual harsh stance on Iran, although he did say it was too soon for the US to meet with the Iranians but there would be talks going forward on the issue of Iran’s ballistic missile programme. G7 host Macron was also upbeat, saying that he hopes for a meeting between Trump and Iranian President Rouhani, adding that conditions have been set for a meeting and a deal could result from one. An Iranian government spokesperson has since said that Tehran has no interests with the US regarding dialogue, and rejected Macron’s proposals for negotiations over its ballistic missile programme; also that Iran had sold the oil from the formerly seized Grace 1 tanker (now called Adrian Darya). Elsewhere, Zarif said he is now in Beijing to brief China on the discussions in France about the 2015 nuclear deal; this comes ahead of the September 5th deadline Iran has given the Europeans to make good on their commitments before Iran further scales back its commitments.

* JAPAN/US: Both nations have reached an in-principle trade agreement, that will see Japan make more purchases of US agricultural goods, while duties on beef and pork will also be cut, although US tariffs on Japanese autos will remain (although, in comments, Trump said he was not looking at auto-tariffs for Japan currently). Elsewhere, Japanese PM Abe says the government has put in place the sufficient steps to support consumption for the tax hike in October.

* DIGITAL TAX: US President Trump said France and the US were close to reaching a compromise on the proposed digital tax. The solution proposes that France repay to companies the difference between a French tax and a planned mechanism being drawn up by the OECD, Reuters reported, citing sources which stated that Trump advisors are said to be pleased with the proposal. The French measure involves a 3% levy on revenue from digital services earned by firms with more than EUR 25mln of French revenues, and EUR 750mln global revenues, which the US has said unfairly targets US names like Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Amazon (AMZN).

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson on Sunday said that if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, it will no longer be legally obliged to pay the GBP 39bln divorce bill agreed by former UK PM May. Johnson reportedly told EU's Tusk at the G7 that the UK would pay less than GBP 10bln in a no deal scenario, with UK outlets suggesting it could be between GBP 7-9bln. EU Brexit coordinator Verhofstadt on Monday said that if the UK does not pay what is due, then the EU will not negotiate a trade deal. Johnson has also sought legal advice on proroguing parliament for five weeks in order to prevent lawmakers from scheming to extend Article 50. Elsewhere, at the G7, Johnson reiterated his position on the backstop (must be jettisoned), ; some reports had suggested that if a "real" solution to the Irish backstop can be found, reopening negotiations on the withdrawal agreement would not be a problem, according to an Express journalist, citing sources. On a US/UK trade deal, President Trump dismissed the notion that any deal would "do over" the UK, while Johnson said he did not want a quick deal that was not maximising opportunities for the UK.

* ITALY: The Bund/BTP spread has narrowed from around 240bps at the open to under 200bps, as it appears that the 5SM and PD are close to agreeing Conte to be PM, while other risk-friendly headlines were also supportive.

* GERMANY IFO: The main three metrics were weaker, dashing the scant hopes for a rebound in Q3. ING's analysts said the free fall of the German economy continues. "IFO index marks another low-point and can be described with one simple word: 'horrible'. Within one year, the German economy has made a complete turnaround, unfortunately not for the better but for the worse." It is worth noting that the significance of the data has been somewhat diminished since it does not include the impact of the latest trade escalations.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLES 5+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-25. While Treasuries are in negative territory, largely on optimism regarding a medley of factors, it is notable that yields, while largely recovering the downside seen on Friday, have not matched the optimism of equity markets, which were trading up by over a percent at one point. It has taken yields longer to rise (at the time equities were up around 1%, yields were only up by around 1bps across the curve; however, at pixel time, equities are off the highs by a margin, and yields are up around 3bps at the short end, and around 2bps at the long-end. Curve spreads are relative flat (+/- 1bps for the major spreads, at settlement); 2s10s once again entered inversion in the European afternoon, although it did not have a detrimental impact on the risk environment. Some traders are more interested by this week’s bund auctions, rather than Treasury auctions. The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (Tue, USD 40bln), new 5-year note (Wed, USD 41bln) and new 7-year note (Thu, USD 32bln). Analysts at UBS say this week will bring USD 85bln of cash (excluding SOMA holdings) but including around USD 76bln of redemption, as well as around USD 8.5bln of coupons.

* WTI FUTURES (V9) SETTLE USD AT USD /BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD AT USD: The energy markets settled lower but have been tracking risk appetite on Monday, where the benchmarks rose to their peaks before the US equity open and then reversed course throughout the session. Participants have been digesting the G7 summit and the latest US-China trade developments, with mixed signals from Beijing and Washington on the current state of play, with Trump spurring optimism whilst comments from China have been on a more cautious tone. However, comments from French President Macron that he hopes for a US President Trump and Iranian President Rouhani summit provided some selling pressure to crude markets. Latest energy expectations…

* FX WRAP: Amid a more constructive environment for risk, JPY’s is the standout. Overnight, USDJPY found lows around 104.50, but has retained the 106.00 handle heading into Asia trade, after optimistic remarks out of the G7 summit gives hope that US and China may once again be making progress on trade (if you buy it, of course), which saw equities up and Treasury yields higher. However, evidence of risk on is not universal: EMFX, for instance is still lagging, as the DXY trades higher by around half-a-percent, while gold retains a bid. Perhaps EMFX is lower, perhaps due to the yuan, where the offshore hit highs around 7.18. Another sign, questioning the sustainability of this risk rally, are the Antipodes, which trade mixed, although the risk-friendly CAD trades slightly positive against the USD. GBP’s gains also reversed amid the overnight risk off, and has failed to make any headway against either the USD or the EUR, despite the latter trading lower against the buck (also of note, EUR strength was lacking amid higher USDCNY – EUR trade weighted basket gives the yuan the largest weighting).

* CNY: Monday's USDCNY fix was broadly in line with expectations (7.0528 vs 7.0572 on Friday), but the currency pair still rose higher in cash markets, printing highs slightly below 7.15. The PBOC also injected CNY 150bln via MLF, rolling over the 149bln that matured at the end of last week. The fix could be a sign that the central bank is trying to calm markets, and not contribute to market jitters. However, analysts are expecting that the escalation of the US/China trade conflict will result in the PBOC guiding is USD/CNY fix higher this week, which in turn will likely apply upward pressure on USD/Asia crosses. UBS notes that EM Asia is still one of the largest foreign credits, and EM FX positions for real money investors, and recommend further hedging since the uncertainty is becoming a dominant theme.

* CHF: Sight deposits held by Swiss commercial banks rose by CHF 3.8bln last week, the largest weekly rise since March 2017, taking the total to a record CHF 589.3bln. Desks note, however, that this still pales in comparison to the spikes of January 2015 (SNB abandoned the EUR/CHF floor of 1.20), as well as in June/July 2016 (post-Brexit vote). SocGen's analysts note that, with the ECB set to cut its deposit rate and restart QE, perhaps at the September meeting, it will force the SNB to cut rates deeper into negative territory, and futures are pricing in a c. 80% chance of a 25bps cut next month. From a technical perspective, SocGen recommends keeping an eye on key support at 1.0825 and then 1.0620.

* S&P 500 +1.1% at 2879, NASDAQ-100 +1.5% at 7575, Dow Jones +1.1% at 25902; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary +1%, Consumer Staples +1.1%, Energy +0.5%, Financials +1.1%, Health Care +1%, Industrials +0.8%, Information Technology +1.4%, Materials +0.3%, Telecommunication Services +1.5%, Utilities +1.2%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: The Trump-inspired trade optimism has fed through to the trade sensitive stocks, which lead gains on Monday, including Apple (AAPL), industrials (UTX, BA, DE) and chipmakers (INTC, NVDA, AMD, MU). Bristol-Myers (BMY) and Celgene (CELG) outperformed after agreeing to divest Celgene’s Otezla drug to Amgen (AMGN) post completion of their pending merger; Amgen opened lower on the news. PDC Energy (PDCE) surged as it announced the acquisition of competitor SRC Energy (SRC). Vici Properties and Dish Networks (DISH) benefitted from upgrades at Morgan Stanley and Raymond James respectively. Beyond Meat (BYND) surged on a KFC (YUM) collaboration. TechnipFMC (FTI) caught a bid on announcing it would separate into two separately public traded companies.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: China still not connecting with US President Trump’s trade calls
content:
JPY

Nowhere near as dramatic, but the Yen was hit by a stop-chase like the Lira overnight when Usd/Jpy broke 105.96 and prevailing intraday peaks through 106.00 to a fresh 106.40 top amidst TV headlines on a business channel tagged as breaking, but old, and research from an asset manager on social media suggesting that the worst may be over in terms of US-China trade wars. However, the headline pair has subsequently drifted all the way back towards the big figure as Chinese officials and journalists continue to play down US President Trump’s claims that high level trade negotiators from Beijing called their US counterparts to re-open dialogue after Friday’s escalation in tariffs from both sides. Moreover, some Chinese observers questioned Trump’s take on a seemingly constructive comment from China’s VP Lui He about the country’s willingness to resolve the spat via ‘calm’ negotiations and whether this was a sign of Beijing backing down. Nevertheless, the Yen remains well off best levels seen at the height of post-Friday risk aversion when it ramped up to 104.50+.

GBP

Also some distance from best levels vs the Usd after the weekend G7 failed to build on Brexit momentum that was riding high after face-to-face meetings between UK PM Johnson and German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron. Cable hit a peak of 1.2285 before fading and slipping back to circa 1.2210 as Johnson conceded that it is still touch and go in terms of reaching a deal with the EU before October 31, while Eur/Gbp mis back above 0.9100 from around 0.9065 at one stage.

CHF 

The Franc and Gold both unwound a degree of their safe-haven premium, but remain underpinned within 0.9810-0.9715 and 1525-55/oz ranges respectively even though Swiss sight deposits rose again to validate speculation that the SNB has been intervening to curb Chf strength/demand.

NZD/EUR/CAD

The Kiwi and Euro had negative fundamentals to deal with on top of a firmer Greenback, with the NZ trade balance swinging from surplus to shortfall overnight and Germany’s Ifo survey weakening further and the institute rather downbeat in accompanying comments as stagnation in Q3 is deemed to be the best that can be anticipated. Nzd/Usd retreated from 0.6395 to sub-0.6350 before consolidating and Eur/Usd pulled back a bit further from 1.1165 to under 1.1110, while Usd/Cad straddled 1.3300 with the Loonie not deriving much direction from choppy oil prices or some knee-jerks in wake of mixed US durable goods data. Note, the DXY did creep over 98.000, but only just awaiting more post-G7 rhetoric from Trump and other leaders. 

AUD

In contrast to the overall trend, the Aussie forged gains vs its US counterpart, albeit partly due to Aud/Nzd cross winds as that pair rebounded from around 1.0530 to 1.0610 or so, with Aud/Usd holding near the upper end of a 0.6773-0.6690 band. Trump’s reports about the state of play on trade with China were a prop, but the Aussie also continued benefit from the RBA’s more balanced outlook and policy stance.

EM

As noted above, the Try suffered very heavy losses in keeping with a flash crash when Japanese margin accounts reportedly liquidated unprofitable long Try/Yen positions overnight. However, the Turkish Lira is back up near 5.8000 compared to almost 6.3000 during Asian trade, but Usd/Cnh remains relatively bid above 7.1600 irrespective of more conciliatory remarks from Trump who is not ruling out another roll-back of Chinese tariffs, and reports of big Chinese banks selling Dollars vs the Yuan.

(UPDATE) ANALYSIS: TRUMP UPS THE ANTE ON CHINA
content:
RECAP: Late-doors last Friday, US President Trump announced a 5ppts increase to the current and impending tariffs on China. This would see the levy on USD 250bln worth of Chinese goods raised to 30% (Prev. 25%) and the looming tax on USD 300bln (starting September 1st) at 15% (Prev. 10%). Meanwhile, US President Trump also insisted that he has the absolute right to order US companies out of China under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act, but added we'll see how it goes. The US President tweeted his announcement hours after China announced retaliatory tariffs on US goods in relation to the upcoming (at the time 10%) levies on the USD 300bln worth of goods. As a reminder, China will tax around USD 75bln US goods at a rate of 5-10%, effective September 1st and December 15th (the same days US tariffs kick-in). Crude oil is among the products to be tariffed at 5% from September 1st, whilst additional auto tariffs of 25% will be reimposed. In terms of agricultural goods, US soybean will see a tax of 5% effective September 1st, US wheat, corn and sorghum at 10% starting December 15th, whilst US beef and pork will also see a tax of 10%.

THE LATEST: Early constructive comments from US President Trump, in which he said he has great respect for President Xi, that China reached out to US negotiators over the weekend and stated that China is ready to come back to the negotiating table and the two countries will start talking very seriously, saw a marked improvement in risk sentiment. Moreover, when asked if he could delay planned tariffs on China, Trump said anything is possible, and added that we are in a much better position now than at any time in trade negotiations. Trump said that an announcement on China will be made later, although its timing and content remain unclear. Rhetoric from the Chinese side has been less constructive (with comments, headlines and tweets from China Global Times editor Hu Xijin weighing on sentiment). In sum; the Chinese Foreign Ministry said they resolutely oppose the US's new tariffs and China will take further steps to protect their interests if the US enacts new tariffs. Moreover, they added that they are not aware of any weekend phone calls between the two nations. Punchy comments from China Global Times editor Hu Xijin later added credence to these comments; he said top Chinese and US negotiators had not held talks in the past few days, but the two sides have been keeping contact at a technical level, before adding China has not changed position and the country will not cave to US pressure. When asked about the Chinese denial of such phone calls, US President Trump doubled down on his earlier claim, saying talks were taking place “at the highest level”. China President Xi later said that China will look to step payments from the central government to important and disadvantaged agricultural producing areas - Agricultural exports has been a key Trump demand, and as such, analysts may see this move by China as a veiled message to the US, amid the most recent trade war escalation.

Should the trade war continue to escalate, what weapons could each nation employ?

1) CHINA’S ARSENAL:

  • Tariff Increase: The current levies announced could increase further to match the effect of US’ tax imposition on the outstanding goods, albeit the size likely to remain the same as the US imports far more goods from China than vice versa.
  • An unreliable entity list: This list could exclude some US firms from doing business with Chinese companies.
  • Rare-earth restrictions: Another “weapon” in China’s arsenal. Prohibiting these rare earth exports to the US will significantly impact hi-tech/electronic producers which may be forced to slow or even halt some US production. SCMP reported earlier this month that China’s rare earth producers are ready to weaponise their supply control and pass any tariffs off via costs to US customers.
  • Yuan: USD/CNH remains above the 7.10 level amid the overall US-China trade landscape. The PBoC previously stated that it will not partake in a competitive devaluation of the Yuan, although the currency move prompted the US to label China as a 'currency manipulator'. Despite this, the daily USD/CNY fixing has been creeping higher, whilst PBoC officials recently reiterated that the Yuan is at an appropriate level at present.

2) TRUMP’S POTENTIAL TIT-FOR-TAT RESPONSE:

  • Tariff Roll-in: The US President could walk back on the tariff delay (i.e. some goods to be taxed on December 15th) which would mean 15% on the full batch of USD 300bln on September 1st. Although this seems to be unlikely as Trump preferably would want to keep goods prices down heading into the Christmas shopping season.
  • Tariff Ramp up: An increase of levvies is nothing new. President Trump has threatened this a few times with the latest announcement made late-doors on Friday.
  • Currency War: Another highly touted move, Trump has constantly criticised the Fed and its policy actions as the reason for a firmer Greenback, whilst also accusing China and Europe of manipulating their currencies. Many desks highlight that Trump could use the US Treasury Department’s Exchange Stability Fund to weaken the USD vs. the CNY.

subject: (UPDATE) ANALYSIS - G7 Summary so far; US/France approach digital tax agreement, US/Germany agree on trade issues
content:
*US/EU:

French and US Finance Officials agreed on a draft proposal on France's digital tax, which will be submitted to heads of state later on Monday, reported sources close to negotiations. US President Trump later alluded to such progress, saying the US and France are getting close to a compromise on the digital issue. Reportedly, the solution proposes that France repay to companies the difference between a French tax and a planned mechanism being drawn up by the OECD, Reuters reported, citing sources which stated that Trump advisors are said to be pleased with the proposal. For reference, the French digital services tax involves a 3% levy on revenue from digital services earned by firms with more than EUR 25mln of French revenues, and EUR 750mln global revenues. The tax has been a point of contention between the US and France/EU; the US saying it unfairly targets US names like Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Amazon (AMZN). 

Seperately, US President Trump said that the US and Germany have reached agreements on a lot of things including trade, adding that he hopes he does not have to consider tariffs on German autos (comments which saw upside in German autonames. Trump also suggested that a trade deal more broadly was discussed with the EU, on which topic, German Chancellor Merkel said that the EU wants to have deeper trade talks with US and a reach a deal soon. 

Although developments seemed largely positive on the US/EU trade front, Trump did have some choice words for the EU, saying the EU is as tough as China on trade and that US has lost lots of money to the EU over the years.

*BREXIT:

While PM Johnson's meetings with German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron prior to the weekend's Summit were designed to prevent Brexit from dominating events, it inevitably cropped up.

Notably, Johnson said that the prospect of a Brexit deal is improving, but the situation remains ‘touch and go’. Discussions between Johnson and European Council President Tusk did not achieve a significant breakthrough; with European officials reiterating the line that it is now up to Britain to find an alternative to the Irish Backstop. Meanwhile, US President Trump commented that Johnson is the correct man to deliver Brexit and a trade deal with Britain could be secured in around one year, although Johnson did play this time-frame down somewhat.

Separately, PM Johnson commented that in the event of a no-deal Britain would not be liable for the GBP 39bln divorce bill.

Overall, the weekend's comments on balance do not alter the lay of land very much. Arguably, a more positive line can be taken from Johnson’s comments that the prospect of a Brexit deal is improving; however, his subsequent caveat and the fact that talks with EU’s Tusk did not produce a breakthrough temper any potential positivity.

*IRAN:

Unexpectedly, Iranian Foreign minister Zarif attended side-line discussions. Consensus appears to be that the US as well as other participants were surprised by the attendance of Zarif. Although, reports indicate that Macron did ask/inform US President Trump of Zarif’s attendance the prior day. Subsequently, US President Trump declined to comment on whether American officials met the foreign minister and that it was too soon for a meeting with Zarif.

It is unclear if the brief meeting between Macron and Zarif yielded any significant progress as Trump has since declined to comment on whether oil sanctions would be waived to have Iran return to the negotiating table; though they are going to discuss ballistic missiles and the duration of any subsequent agreement with Iran.

As a reminder, the nations' relationship has significantly deteriorated since the US withdrew from the 2015 Iranian nuclear deal and Iran began increasing its nuclear activity (typically reported via the proportion of enriched uranium, with the latest figures indicating an excess of 300kg) due to economic sanctions being reimposed.

*BRAZIL:

While the economic implications of this are somewhat overlooked by, among other things, the ongoing US-China trade war, French President Macron has called upon global leaders to assist Brazil in fighting the Amazon wildfires. With some reports indicating that PM Bolsonaro and Environment Minister Salles’ policies have encouraged the fires through policies they have undertaken since attaining office.

In terms of implications, most notably EU Council President Tusk stated that while the EU stands by the EU-Mercosur trade agreement (free trade deal between the EU and South American Nations) it is hard to envisage a ‘harmonious process of ratification’ so long as the Brazilian government allows the forest to be destroyed. Specifically, France and Ireland have threatened to block the agreement if Brazilian president Bolsonaro does not act to slow the deforestation rate.

For context, the EU-Mercosur deal was agreed to in principal earlier in the year, following on from around 20 years of negotiations. Countries involved include Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. The deal would indicatively eliminate 93% of export tariffs to the EU, with the remainder under a ‘preferential treatment’ arrangement, while 91% of export tariffs to Mercosur countries would be removed.

ANALYSIS: Italy's PD and 5SM talks hit sticking point
content:
*THE LATEST: Talks between PD and 5SM, who entered into discussions last week for the formation of a new government, have hit a sticking point; 5SM want former PM Conte to continue as PM of the new coalition but PD do not. PD Leader Zingaretti wants the new government to mark a “change” from the policies of the former 5SM-Lega coalition and, for this reason, opposes the reappointment of the old PM. However, talks between the two parties have seen some progress; PD accepted 5-Star's request to reduce the number of MPs (provided that there are constitutional guarantees), PD’s Senate Leader said there will be no vetos on Conte as PM, comments which saw strength in BTPs and PD lawmaker said that discussions with the 5SM were positive, provided good reason for hope and presented no insurmountable obstacles.

*NEXT STEP: President Sergio Mattarella has given the M5S and the PD untill Wednesday evening to form an agreement, otherwise, he is likely to call early elections for October 27, say Italian media. Mattarella's deadline had originally been for Tuesday, so it appears to have been moved back one day. 

*ELECTIONS: League Leader Salvini said he will not resign and will remain as Interior Minister, while he will ask President Mattarella for early elections and stated there is no plan B besides an early vote. The timing of an election is subject to the Parliamentary reform which aims for a reduction in MPs, which HSBC says would mean elections could not take place for another five to six months at least, due to the need to allow a possible referendum to be called, and to re-draw the electoral boundaries. 

*LATEST POLLING: Comparing the 2018 general election results to current polls: League currently leads polls at 37% (it currently has 17.4% of the seats in the Lower House), PD follows in the polls with 23% (vs current 18.8%) and 5SM with 18% (vs current 32.7%). In terms of the smaller parties, Brothers of Italy poll at 7% (vs 4.4% in Parliament) and Forza Italia is polling at 6% (vs. current 14%)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 26th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • A plethora of US-China comments thus far has resulted in choppy risk sentiment, overall Trump has been constructive though China remains negative
  • US President Trump stated that the sides held talks over the weekend though, China denied all knowledge of this and Trump added that anything is possible in the context of delaying planned tariffs
  • European bourses are firmer and both WTI and Brent remain supported on the more positive comments from US President trump thus far, DXY is stronger and fixed lacks clear direction thus far
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods and UK Summer Bank Holiday

US-CHINA TRADE

* Weekend

US President Trump announced to raise tariffs on China on Friday by another 5ppts in which the tariffs on USD 250bln of goods from China will be increased to 30% from 25% on October 1st, while the planned 10% tariffs on the remaining USD 300bln of goods from China which are due from September 1st will be taxed at 15%. (Twitter)

US President Trump suggested that he has the absolute right to order US companies out of China under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act but added we'll see how it goes. (Newswires/ABC)

China Vice Premier Liu He said China is willing to resolves trade dispute with US through calm negotiations and resolutely opposes escalation of trade war which is not beneficial for both sides. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor stated that China is seriously making preparations for a scenario in which China-US trade relations further deteriorate..(Twitter)

* Monday

US President Trump says China called US trade negotiators last night and want to return to the negotiation table, adding that Chinese President Xi is a great leader. There will be a further statement on China. We will start to negotiate shortly, believes we will make a deal; China does not want to lose its supply chains.

US President Trump, when asked if he could delay planned tariffs on China, says anything is possible, adds that we are in a much better position now than at any time in trade negotiations. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry say they resolutely oppose the US's new tariffs, and China will take further steps to protect their interests if the US enacts new tariffs; Not aware of a US-China weekend phone call. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor says top Chinese and US negotiators have not held talks in the past few days, but the two sides have been keeping contact at a technical level; adds China has not changed position, will not cave to US pressure. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets tracked last Friday’s hefty losses on Wall Street and the continued weakness in US index futures at the reopen due to the escalation in the US-China trade war. ASX 200 (-1.2%) was led lower by underperformance in energy after the recent slump in oil and as the tech sector suffered the brunt of the latest trade aggressions, although gold miners bucked the trend after the precious metal surged on a safe-haven bid. Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) was heavily pressured with losses for exporters exacerbated by detrimental currency flows, while Hang Seng (-1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) slumped amid the trade concerns. Furthermore, Hong Kong was the worst performer amid further unrest as police were said to have beaten protesters and fired tear gas at an anti-surveillance rally over the weekend. Conversely, some of the losses were later pared after China’s Vice Premier Liu He stated that China is willing to resolve the dispute through calm negotiation and resolutely opposes escalation of the trade war, while India markets were intially underpinned after the Finance Minister recently announced several measures to support the economy including a withdrawal of capital gains tax enhanced surcharge and a INR 700bln bank recapitalization but then gradually deteriorated alongside the broad risk averse tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned by a safe-haven bid and which coincided with upside in USTs as the US 10yr yield drop to a fresh 3-year low, with the BoJ also present in the market for 10yr+ and inflation indexed bonds. 

PBoC skipped open market operations but announced CNY 150bln of medium-term lending facility operations at 3.3% vs. Prev. 3.3%. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0570 vs. Exp. 7.0528 (Prev. 7.0572)

Hong Kong riot police were said to have beaten protesters and fired tear gas at an anti-surveillance rally over the weekend, while the police were also said to have used a water cannon for the first time ever and an office reportedly fired a warning shot. (Newswires)

US and Japan reached a framework for a trade agreement in which auto tariffs will remain unchanged and US will delay decision on Japan auto tariffs. Furthermore, reports added that Japan will reduce tariffs on US beef and pork, while Japan is said to have agreed to import an additional 2.5mln tonnes of feed corn from the US and the sides aim to sign a deal by September. (Newswires/Nikkei)

 

US

Fed’s Mester (Non-voter, Hawk) said she is undecided for September FOMC meeting but added that the Fed may need to cut rates to avoid restraining the economy if the economic outlook deteriorates, while she also stated that Chinese counter tariffs are just a continuation of the trade uncertainty that has been with us for some time and reiterated that the Fed should be data dependent. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

EU diplomat stated that no agreement or progress was made towards persuading US President Trump to reissue oil sanction waivers at the G7, while there were separate reports Britain will be sending another warship to the Persian Gulf to support safe passage of shipping. (Newswires)

North Korea conducted another missile test over the weekend. (Newswires)

Iranian Revolutionary Guard said Iran tested a new missile. (Newswires)

China Defence Ministry urged the US to stop arms sales to Taiwan and cut its military ties with the country. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin has ordered Russia's military to prepare measures in response to US missile tests and wants the military to take exhaustive measures to prepare for a reciprocal response, according to Russia's Kremlin. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson at the G7 Summit said the prospect of a Brexit deal is ‘improving’ but that the situation still remains ‘touch and go’, adding that Britain would not be obliged to pay the GBP 39bln divorce bill in the event of a no-deal. However, UK Government lawyers have reportedly drawn up a range of scenarios for no-deal; including one where Britain is legally obliged to pay the GBP 39bln. (Times/Sky/Telegraph)

US President Trump said that without the EU acting as an ‘anchor’ a ‘very big trade deal’ could be secured within around one year following Brexit. Although, PM Johnson cautioned that it could take longer. (Times)

UK Chancellor Javid is reportedly mulling an emergency budget if a no-deal Brexit seems imminent in late October. (Times)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier stated we are ready to analyse UK proposals that are realistic, operational & compatible with our principles but added the WA is the best possible deal. (Newswires)

Sources say that if a "real" solution to the Irish backstop can be found, reopening negotiations on the WA would not be a problem, says the Express's Barnes. (Twitter)

European Council President Tusk said the bloc will respond in kind if the is imposes tariffs on France regarding its digital taxation plan, while he suggested there could be a risk to whole world if US President Trump imposes tariffs for political reasons. (Newswires)

EU plans to simplify Eurozone budget rules and may soften debt reduction targets. (FT)

ECB’s Weidmann (Hawk) stated that any review of the ECB’s policy should take place under new the new ECB President Lagarde, who is due to take office on November 1st. (Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung)

Italy’s 5-Star and PD parties are reportedly struggling to find a deal on a new government ahead of the Tuesday deadline. (Newswires)

French and US Finance Officials have agreed on a draft proposal on France's digital tax, which will be submitted to heads of state later on Monday, according to sources close to negotiations. US President Trump says US and France are getting close to a compromise on the digital issue .(Newswires)

German IFO Business Climate Index 94.3 vs. Exp. 95.1 (Rev. 95.8); current conditions 97.3 vs. Exp. 98.8 (Rev. 99.6); expectations 91.3 vs. Exp. 91.5 (Rev. 92.1) (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +0.6%] after US President Trump adopted a constructive tone regarding talks with China, whilst upside in the region was exacerbated after the US President stated the US and Germany have reached agreements on a number of subjects including trade, whilst also noting that US and France are getting close to a compromise on the digital tax issue. However, bourses came off highs after China Global Times editor noted that US and Chinese negotiators did not hold a phone call. Nonetheless, stocks are still supported by hopes of potential tariffs delays on China. Sectors are mixed with no clear winner/laggard. In terms of individual movers, UBS (-1.4%) shares fell after source reports that the bank reportedly explored an alliance with Deutsche Bank (+0.3%). Meanwhile, EssilorLuxoticca (+1.2%) shares spiked higher amid reports that ThirdPoint LLC have acquired a stake in the Co. Note, the FTSE is closed due to UK Summer Bank Holiday today.

Tesla (TSLA) - Co. are reportedly to raise prices on August 30th in China, which is earlier than planned. And are also said to be considering increasing prices in December for China if tariffs on US produced cars are implemented., according to sources. (Newswires)

FX

JPY/CHF/XAU - The major safe-havens have retreated from lofty overnight peaks amidst comments from US President Trump at the G7 about conversations between Chinese and US officials following Friday’s reciprocal ramp up of tariffs that could bring the 2 sides back to the negotiating table. Even though China’s Foreign Ministry is unaware of any such calls, the markets are waiting for a statement from Trump with risk aversion receding in the run up. Hence, Usd/Jpy, Usd/Chf and Xau/Usd are extending their retracement to circa 106.00, 0.9785 and 1525/oz from just shy of 104.50, 0.9710 and 1555 respectively at one stage, to the benefit of the DXY that is rebounding towards 98.000 vs 97.618 at the low.

GBP/NZD/EUR/CAD - All on the defensive as the Greenback broadly recovers as noted above, but with Sterling also losing more of its Brexit positivity after UK PM Johnson cautioned that while prospects of reaching a deal have improved it remains a close call. Cable is back down around 1.2235 compared to 1.2285 at best, which coincided with a Fib retracement and resistance level ahead of 1.2300 as well, while Nzd/Usd remains toppy on approaches to 0.6400 and is still underperforming vs the AUD as the cross rebounds to 1.0600 and Aussie derives more traction from the latest Trump tweets within a 0.6765-0.6690 range. Note also, the Kiwi was not helped by NZ trade data showing a deficit as imports eclipsed exports in July. Elsewhere, the Euro is slipping back towards 1.1100 from 1.1165 with additional pressure, albeit incremental, coming via a dire German Ifo survey and the institute clarifying that the declines in business sentiment, current conditions and expectations did not take into account latest trade war escalations, though this is hardly surprising given the timing of the August poll. Last but not least, the Loonie is still pivoting 1.3300 and not gleaning any independent impetus from Canadian data, but US durable goods may impact as the series of often erratic.

EM - Some calm after the overnight risk-off storm, and especially for the Turkish Lira that suffered losses in keeping with a flash crash when Japanese margin accounts are said to have liquidated unprofitable long Try/Yen positions. Usd/Try is back down near 5.8200 compared to almost 6.3000 during Asian trade, but Usd/Cny remains relatively bid above 7.1500 irrespective of more conciliatory remarks from Trump who is not ruling out another roll-back of Chinese tariffs, and reports of big Chinese banks selling Dollars vs the Yuan.

FIXED INCOME

The risk roller-coaster continues to hurtle along and the latest twist of the white knuckle ride has seen US Treasuries lead other core bonds on an incline after Hu Xijin of the Global Times chimes with China’s Foreign Ministry in denying knowledge of any phone conversations between top officials from Washington and Beijing over the weekend. UST futures are back above parity and the curve a bit flatter, while Bunds are off 178.22 lows (-32 ticks on the day) but still some distance from best levels (179.21) in UK-light trading conditions due to the late August bank holiday. Ahead, US durable goods that is often volatile and off-consensus plus more regional activity surveys for August, but US-China headlines, tweets and reports remain at the fore.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are marginally in positive territory as the benchmarks ride on the current “risk on” wave in the markets after US President Trump took a constructive stance regarding US-Sino trade dialogue, ahead of an announcement on China later today; however recent comments from China’s Global Times Editor have paired back much of this positivity. WTI futures have just climbed above the 54.50/bbl level whilst its Brent counterpart eyes 60/bbl to the upside. In terms of geopolitics, Iranian Foreign minister Zarif unexpectedly attended side-line discussions at the G7 summit. It is unclear if the brief meeting between Macron and Zarif yielded any significant progress as US President Trump has since declined to comment on whether oil sanctions would be waived to have Iran return to the negotiating table; though they are going to discuss ballistic missiles and the duration of any subsequent agreement with Iran. Participants will today be eyeing trade developments as a catalyst, with US President Trump set to make an announcement later today, although no specific time was mentioned. In terms of US President Trump's scheduling for the day, aside from the scheduled G7 pressers, he is to hold a press conference with French President Macron at 14:30BST. Elsewhere, gold prices have retreated after printing fresh 6-year highs on the back of trade developments, which saw the precious metal soar above 1550/oz early Asia-Pac trade. Meanwhile, copper prices saw a firm rebound after briefly breaching 2.5/lb to the downside. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices saw renewed downside amid President Trump’s announcement on Friday that tariffs on China (current and impending) will be raised by 5ppts.

Cable is back down around 1.2235 compared to 1.2285 at best, which coincided with a Fib retracement and resistance level ahead of 1.2300 as well, while Nzd/Usd remains toppy on approaches to 0.6400 and is still underperforming vs the AUD as the cross rebounds to 1.0600 and Aussie derives more traction from the latest Trump tweets within a 0.6765-0.6690 range. Note also, the Kiwi was not helped by NZ trade data showing a deficit as imports eclipsed exports in July. Elsewhere, the Euro is slipping back towards 1.1100 from 1.1165 with additional pressure, albeit incremental, coming via a dire German Ifo survey and the institute clarifying that the declines in business sentiment, current conditions and expectations did not take into account latest trade war escalations, though this is hardly surprising given the timing of the August poll. Last but not least, the Loonie is still pivoting 1.3300 and not gleaning any independent impetus from Canadian data, but US durable goods may impact as the series of often erratic.

EM 

Some calm after the overnight risk-off storm, and especially for the Turkish Lira that suffered losses in keeping with a flash crash when Japanese margin accounts are said to have liquidated unprofitable long Try/Yen positions. Usd/Try is back down near 5.8200 compared to almost 6.3000 during Asian trade, but Usd/Cny remains relatively bid above 7.1500 irrespective of more conciliatory remarks from Trump who is not ruling out another roll-back of Chinese tariffs, and reports of big Chinese banks selling Dollars vs the Yuan.

subject: US President Trump, when asked if he could delay planned tariffs on China, says anything is possible, adds that we are in a much better position now than at any time in trade negotiations
reaction_details: In an immediate reaction to this comment, European and US equity futures jumped higher; US equity futures now trade with gains of over 1%, European equity futures over 0.5% higher whilst WTI and Brent briefly surpassed the USD 55 and USD 60 per barrel marks respectively.
analysis_details:
LONG STORY SHORT: US President Trump, late-doors on Friday announced a 5ppts increase to the current and impending tariffs on China. This would see the levy on USD 250bln worth of Chinese goods raised to 30% (Prev. 25%) and the looming tax on USD 300bln (starting September 1st) at 15% (Prev. 10%). Meanwhile, US President Trump also insisted that he has the absolute right to order US companies out of China under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act, but added we'll see how it goes.

REAR VIEW:  The US President tweeted his announcement hours after China announced retaliatory tariffs on US goods in relation to the upcoming (at the time 10%) levies on the USD 300bln worth of goods. As a reminder, China will tax around USD 75bln US goods at a rate of 5-10%, effective September 1st and December 15th (the same days US tariffs kick-in). Crude oil is among the products to be tariffed at 5% from September 1st, whilst additional auto tariffs of 25% will be reimposed. In terms of agricultural goods, US soybean will see a tax of 5% effective September 1st, US wheat, corn and sorghum at 10% starting December 15th, whilst US beef and pork will also see a tax of 10%.

CHINA RHETORIC: Over the weekend, China Global Times’ Chief Editor tweeted that China is seriously preparing for a scenario in which China-US trade relations further deteriorate. He also suggested that if US and China decouple, China can independently develop technology, but the US can't find an alternative market with China's potential, while he added that China will meet short-term difficulties without the US and that the US will lose its driving force of long-term growth without China. However, Vice Premier Lui He took a more conciliatory tone, stating that China is willing to resolve the trade dispute with the US through calm negotiations and resolutely opposes the escalation of trade wars, which is not beneficial for either side. Meanwhile, at its daily presser, China’s Foreign Ministry stated that China resolutely opposes the new tariffs and China will take further steps to protect its interests if the US enacts new tariffs.

US RHETORIC: At a G7 presser, US President Trump adopted a somewhat optimistic tone, as he noted that he has great respect for President Xi and that China reached out to US negotiators over the weekend, stating that China is ready to come back to the negotiating table and the two countries will start talking very seriously. US President Trump also said that an announcement on China will be made later. However, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Geng stated that he is not aware of any weekend phone calls between the two nations.

ANALYSIS - G7 Summary so far: Brexit features, a Zarif surprise and wildfires threaten South American-EU trade
content:
*BREXIT:

  • While PM Johnson's meetings with German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron prior to the weekend's Summit were designed to prevent Brexit from dominating events, it inevitably cropped up.
  • Notably, Johnson said that the prospect of a Brexit deal is improving, but the situation remains ‘touch and go’. Discussions between Johnson and European Council President Tusk did not achieve a significant breakthrough; with European officials reiterating the line that it is now up to Britain to find an alternative to the Irish Backstop. Meanwhile, US President Trump commented that Johnson is the correct man to deliver Brexit and a trade deal with Britain could be secured in around one year, although Johnson did play this time-frame down somewhat.
  • Separately, PM Johnson commented that in the event of a no-deal Britain would not be liable for the GBP 39bln divorce bill.
  • Overall, the weekend's comments on balance do not alter the lay of land very much. Arguably, a more positive line can be taken from Johnson’s comments that the prospect of a Brexit deal is improving; however, his subsequent caveat and the fact that talks with EU’s Tusk did not produce a breakthrough temper any potential positivity.

*IRAN:

  • Unexpectedly, Iranian Foreign minister Zarif attended side-line discussions. Consensus appears to be that the US as well as other participants were surprised by the attendance of Zarif. Although, reports indicate that Macron did ask/inform US President Trump of Zarif’s attendance the prior day. Subsequently, US President Trump declined to comment on whether American officials met the foreign minister and that it was too soon for a meeting with Zarif.
  • It is unclear if the brief meeting between Macron and Zarif yielded any significant progress as Trump has since declined to comment on whether oil sanctions would be waived to have Iran return to the negotiating table; though they are going to discuss ballistic missiles and the duration of any subsequent agreement with Iran.
  • As a reminder, the nations' relationship has significantly deteriorated since the US withdrew from the 2015 Iranian nuclear deal and Iran began increasing its nuclear activity (typically reported via the proportion of enriched uranium, with the latest figures indicating an excess of 300kg) due to economic sanctions being reimposed.

*BRAZIL

  • While the economic implications of this are somewhat overlooked by, among other things, the ongoing US-China trade war, French President Macron has called upon global leaders to assist Brazil in fighting the Amazon wildfires. With some reports indicating that PM Bolsonaro and Environment Minister Salles’ policies have encouraged the fires through policies they have undertaken since attaining office.
  • In terms of implications, most notably EU Council President Tusk stated that while the EU stands by the EU-Mercosur trade agreement (free trade deal between the EU and South American Nations) it is hard to envisage a ‘harmonious process of ratification’ so long as the Brazilian government allows the forest to be destroyed. Specifically, France and Ireland have threatened to block the agreement if Brazilian president Bolsonaro does not act to slow the deforestation rate.
  • For context, the EU-Mercosur deal was agreed to in principal earlier in the year, following on from around 20 years of negotiations. Countries involved include Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. The deal would indicatively eliminate 93% of export tariffs to the EU, with the remainder under a ‘preferential treatment’ arrangement, while 91% of export tariffs to Mercosur countries would be removed.

ANALYSIS: TRUMP UPPED THE ANTE ON CHINA
content:
LONG STORY SHORT: US President Trump, late-doors on Friday announced a 5ppts increase to the current and impending tariffs on China. This would see the levy on USD 250bln worth of Chinese goods raised to 30% (Prev. 25%) and the looming tax on USD 300bln (starting September 1st) at 15% (Prev. 10%). Meanwhile, US President Trump also insisted that he has the absolute right to order US companies out of China under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act, but added we'll see how it goes.

REAR VIEW:  The US President tweeted his announcement hours after China announced retaliatory tariffs on US goods in relation to the upcoming (at the time 10%) levies on the USD 300bln worth of goods. As a reminder, China will tax around USD 75bln US goods at a rate of 5-10%, effective September 1st and December 15th (the same days US tariffs kick-in). Crude oil is among the products to be tariffed at 5% from September 1st, whilst additional auto tariffs of 25% will be reimposed. In terms of agricultural goods, US soybean will see a tax of 5% effective September 1st, US wheat, corn and sorghum at 10% starting December 15th, whilst US beef and pork will also see a tax of 10%.

CHINA RHETORIC: Over the weekend, China Global Times’ Chief Editor tweeted that China is seriously preparing for a scenario in which China-US trade relations further deteriorate. He also suggested that if US and China decouple, China can independently develop technology, but the US can't find an alternative market with China's potential, while he added that China will meet short-term difficulties without the US and that the US will lose its driving force of long-term growth without China. However, Vice Premier Lui He took a more conciliatory tone, stating that China is willing to resolve the trade dispute with the US through calm negotiations and resolutely opposes the escalation of trade wars, which is not beneficial for either side. Meanwhile, at its daily presser, China’s Foreign Ministry stated that China resolutely opposes the new tariffs and China will take further steps to protect its interests if the US enacts new tariffs.

US RHETORIC: At a G7 presser, US President Trump adopted a somewhat optimistic tone, as he noted that he has great respect for President Xi and that China reached out to US negotiators over the weekend, stating that China is ready to come back to the negotiating table and the two countries will start talking very seriously. US President Trump also said that an announcement on China will be made later. However, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Geng stated that he is not aware of any weekend phone calls between the two nations.

 

1) CHINA’S ARSENAL:

  • Tariff Increase: The current levies announced could increase further to match the effect of US’ tax imposition on the outstanding goods, albeit the size likely to remain the same as the US imports far more goods from China than vice versa.
  • An unreliable entity list: This list could exclude some US firms from doing business with Chinese companies.
  • Rare-earth restrictions: Another “weapon” in China’s arsenal. Prohibiting these rare earth exports to the US will significantly impact hi-tech/electronic producers which may be forced to slow or even halt some US production. SCMP reported earlier this month that China’s rare earth producers are ready to weaponise their supply control and pass any tariffs off via costs to US customers.
  • Yuan: USD/CNH remains above the 7.10 level amid the overall US-China trade landscape. The PBoC previously stated that it will not partake in a competitive devaluation of the Yuan, although the currency move prompted the US to label China as a 'currency manipulator'. Despite this, the daily USD/CNY fixing has been creeping higher, whilst PBoC officials recently reiterated that the Yuan is at an appropriate level at present.

2) TRUMP’S POTENTIAL TIT-FOR-TAT RESPONSE:

  • Tariff Roll-in: The US President could walk back on the tariff delay (i.e. some goods to be taxed on December 15th) which would mean 15% on the full batch of USD 300bln on September 1st. Although this seems to be unlikely as Trump preferably would want to keep goods prices down heading into the Christmas shopping season.
  • Tariff Ramp up: An increase of levvies is nothing new. President Trump has threatened this a few times with the latest announcement made late-doors on Friday.
  • Currency War: Another highly touted move, Trump has constantly criticised the Fed and its policy actions as the reason for a firmer Greenback, whilst also accusing China and Europe of manipulating their currencies. Many desks highlight that Trump could use the US Treasury Department’s Exchange Stability Fund to weaken the USD vs. the CNY.

content: The 10 year German benchmark gapped up off the open to 179.08 vs last Friday’s 178.54 Eurex close and saw some follow-through buying to an overnight high of 179.21 before fading amidst conciliatory comments from China’s VP Lui He in wake of the latest ramp up in tariffs from US President Trump and Beijing that sparked another bout of risk-off trade in the financial markets. However, the core Eurozone bond did not glean enough momentum to test the mid-August contract peak and is now just off a 178.52 low awaiting the EU stock opens and digesting typically hawkish comments from ECB’s Weidmann alongside reports that the EU may relax debt reduction rules while simplifying budget regulations in general. Ahead, Germany’s Ifo survey is expected to reveal a deterioration in all 3 components.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

26th August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

*Note: UK Summer Bank Holiday – FTSE 100 is therefore closed*

ASIA

Asian equity markets tracked last Friday’s hefty losses on Wall Street and the continued weakness in US index futures at the reopen due to the escalation in the US-China trade war. ASX 200 (-1.4%) was led lower by underperformance in energy after the recent slump in oil and as the tech sector suffered the brunt of the latest trade aggressions, although gold miners bucked the trend after the precious metal surged on a safe-haven bid. Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) was heavily pressured with losses for exporters exacerbated by detrimental currency flows, while Hang Seng (-2.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) slumped amid the trade concerns. Furthermore, Hong Kong was the worst performer amid further unrest as police were said to have beaten protesters and fired tear gas at an anti-surveillance rally over the weekend. Conversely, some of the losses were later pared after China’s Vice Premier Liu He stated that China is willing to resolve the dispute through calm negotiation and resolutely opposes escalation of the trade war, while India markets were intially underpinned after the Finance Minister recently announced several measures to support the economy including a withdrawal of capital gains tax enhanced surcharge and a INR 700bln bank recapitalization but then gradually deteriorated alongside the broad risk averse tone.
